keywords.significance: Source of authority is the people (popular sovereignty)
India is supreme, not subordinate to any external power
Economic justice, reduce inequalities (Added by 42nd Amendment 1976)
No state religion, equal respect to all religions (Added by 42nd Amendment 1976)
Government by the people, of the people, for the people
Head of State is elected, not hereditary
Social, Economic, Political justice for all citizens
Freedom of thought, expression, belief, faith, worship
Of status and opportunity - no discrimination
Spirit of brotherhood, dignity of individual, unity and integrity of nation

basicFacts: **Source**: Inspired by 'Objectives Resolution' moved by Jawaharlal Nehru on December 13, 1946
**Called**: 'Soul of the Constitution' (T.T. Krishnamachari) or 'Identity Card' of Constitution
**Nature**: Neither part of Constitution nor can be used to amend Constitution (court held)
**Amendability**: Preamble is amendable under Art 368 (Kesavananda Bharati case 1973)
keyTerms: **1. WE, THE PEOPLE** - Popular sovereignty; authority derives from people, not King or Parliament
**2. SOVEREIGN** - India is independent; no external power can dictate; full power over internal and external affairs
**3. SOCIALIST** - Democratic socialism (not communist); economic justice; reduce inequalities; welfare state [Added 42nd Amendment]
**4. SECULAR** - No state religion; equal respect to all religions; State neutral; freedom of religion [Added 42nd Amendment]
**5. DEMOCRATIC** - Government elected by people; representative democracy; adult franchise; rule of majority with minority rights
**6. REPUBLIC** - Head of State (President) elected for fixed term; not hereditary monarch; promotes equality
**7. JUSTICE** - Social (no discrimination), Economic (no exploitation, equal opportunity), Political (equal political rights)
**8. LIBERTY** - Freedom of thought, expression, belief, faith, worship; essential for democratic functioning
**9. EQUALITY** - Of status (no titles except military/academic), Of opportunity (equal chance in public employment, education)
**10. FRATERNITY** - Spirit of brotherhood; dignity of individual (respect for human rights); unity and integrity of Nation
**11. INTEGRITY** - Territorial, political, social integrity; added by 42nd Amendment 1976 (only 'unity' was there earlier)
42ndAmendment: **Before amendment**: 'Sovereign Democratic Republic' and 'unity of the Nation'
**After amendment**: 'Sovereign Socialist Secular Democratic Republic' and 'unity and integrity of the Nation'
**Reason**: Explicitly state India's socialist and secular nature; emphasize territorial integrity (after 1971 Bangladesh creation)
**Controversy**: Added during Emergency (when democratic processes suspended)
keyCases: **Berubari Union case (1960)** - Preamble is not part of Constitution; cannot be used to amend Constitution
**Kesavananda Bharati (1973)** - Overruled Berubari; Preamble is part of Constitution; amendable under Art 368; reflects basic structure
**S.R. Bommai (1994)** - Secularism is basic feature; part of basic structure (cannot be amended)
**Union Carbide case (1989)** - Preamble indicates ideals and aspirations; can be used to interpret ambiguous provisions
examTips: **Most asked**: 42nd Amendment (1976) added SOCIALIST, SECULAR, INTEGRITY
**Remember**: SOVEREIGN, SOCIALIST, SECULAR, DEMOCRATIC, REPUBLIC - 5 key terms describing polity
**Objectives**: JUSTICE (3 types), LIBERTY (5 freedoms), EQUALITY (2 types), FRATERNITY (2 aspects)
**Called**: Soul of Constitution (T.T. Krishnamachari), Identity Card (N.A. Palkhivala)
**Key difference**: SOCIALIST in Preamble = Democratic socialism (not communism); SECULAR = Sarva Dharma Sambhava (equal respect), not anti-religion
socialismExplained: **NOT communist socialism** (no dictatorship, no single party, no abolition of private property)
**Democratic socialism**: Mixed economy; public + private sector; welfare state; reduce inequalities
**Features**: Economic justice, DPSP implementation, affirmative action, pro-poor policies
**Reflects**: DPSP like Art 38 (welfare), Art 39 (equal pay, livelihood), Art 39(b) (common good)
secularismExplained: **Indian secularism** = Sarva Dharma Sambhava (equal respect for all religions)
**Features**: No state religion, freedom of religion (Art 25-28), State equidistant from all religions, can regulate religious practices
**Different from Western secularism**: Western = complete separation; Indian = equal respect and intervention for social reform
**Allows**: State to interfere for social reform (abolish untouchability, allow temple entry, Hindu Code Bill)
sources: **USSR**: 'Socialist' (economic model, though India's is democratic socialism)
**Objectives Resolution**: Jawaharlal Nehru's Objectives Resolution (1947) is the foundation
**Indian values**: Fraternity, dignity, unity reflect Indian philosophical traditions
